text.p: How many [mathjaxinline]3\times 3[/mathjaxinline] orthogonal matrices have [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] as their first column and [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline] as their second column? Enter 'infinite' if you think there are infinitely many. (Hint: Think geometrically!)

font.p: A [mathjaxinline]3\times 3[/mathjaxinline] matrix is orthogonal if and only if its columns form an orthonormal basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline]. Thus, the question is equivalent to asking, how many vectors [mathjaxinline]v_3[/mathjaxinline] are there such that [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is an orthonormal basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline].

Notice that [mathjaxinline]\| v_1\| = \| v_2\| = 1[/mathjaxinline], and that [mathjaxinline]\langle v_1, v_2 \rangle = 0.[/mathjaxinline] So we are two-thirds of the way to forming an orthonormal basis of [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline]. If [mathjaxinline]\{ v_1; v_2; v_3\}[/mathjaxinline] is to be orthonormal, we must have [mathjaxinline]v_3[/mathjaxinline] of norm 1, and orthogonal to the plane spanned by [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]v_2[/mathjaxinline]. There are exactly two unit vectors orthogonal to a given plane (one on each side). Thus there are exactly two ways to fill out the third column to make the matrix orthogonal.
